article.title: Triangulum II: Not Especially Dense After All

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of object is Triangulum II most likely to be?
choices: Globular Cluster
Dwarf Galaxy
Giant Elliptical Galaxy
Planetary Nebula

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the spatial distribution of member stars in Triangulum II suggest?
choices: The stars are concentrated in the center, indicating a strong gravitational potential.
The stars are evenly distributed, suggesting a lack of dark matter.
The stars show a clumpy distribution, possibly indicating recent star formation.
The spatial distribution alone cannot distinguish between a galaxy and a star cluster.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the difference in velocity dispersion at larger radii (r > 2\') between this study and the M16 study?
choices: This study includes more member stars at larger radii.
This study excludes star 25, a double-lined spectroscopic binary.
This study uses higher signal-to-noise velocity measurements, resulting in different values for some individual stars.
This study adopts a different method for calculating velocity dispersion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the distribution of σv in the MCMC trials for Triangulum II indicate?
choices: The velocity dispersion is well-constrained and indicates a large amount of dark matter.
The velocity dispersion cannot be resolved with the available data.
The velocity dispersion is consistent with zero, suggesting Triangulum II is not a gravitationally bound system.
The velocity dispersion is significantly higher than expected, challenging our understanding of dark matter.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the metallicity dispersion change when star 31 and star 46 are excluded?
choices: The metallicity dispersion becomes much larger, suggesting a wider range of stellar populations.
The metallicity dispersion becomes much smaller, implying a more homogeneous stellar population.
The metallicity dispersion becomes only marginally resolved, making it difficult to draw strong conclusions.
The exclusion of these stars has no significant impact on the metallicity dispersion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the trend of [α/Fe] with increasing [Fe/H] in Triangulum II suggest about its chemical evolution?
choices: It suggests enrichment primarily by Type II supernovae, typical of dwarf galaxies.
It indicates enrichment dominated by Type Ia supernovae at late times, similar to other UFDs.
It shows no clear trend, making it difficult to draw conclusions about its chemical evolution.
It shows a unique pattern not observed in other galaxies, challenging current theories of chemical evolution.
